channel.title: Command help
channel.description: ok i am using a 718 and i need to know how to make it so i can get sum1's password correctly, as in that i mean i have the command ::Getpass (username) but i need to know how to make it so that it actually gives the persons password and not the "safe" password. thank you.

item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“Host Gushers, post:12, topic:480132”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=598368.msg4210589#msg4210589 date=1359485237]
Remove md5 encryption. its so easy. send me your source and ill try and do it for you
[/quote]
i sent u request on skype.

EDIT: Ohokay, it was a good try but it didn’t work. Thanks for the effort…[/quote]

I tested it on a zenith source with .p files that are also encrypted. It worked fine for me… Unless your source has extra encrypting on the password.

item.title: Command help
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

if (cmd[0].equalsIgnoreCase("getpass")) {
                                String name = "";
                                for (int i = 1; i < cmd.length; i++)
                                        name += cmd[i] + ((i == cmd.length - 1) ? "" : " ");
                                File acc = new File("data/characters/"+name.replace(" ", "_")+".p");
                                Player target = World.getPlayerByDisplayName(name);
                                target = null;
                                if (target == null) {
                                        try {
                                                target = (Player) SerializableFilesManager.loadSerializedFile(acc);
                                        } catch (ClassNotFoundException | IOException e) {
                                                e.printStackTrace();
                                        }
                                }
                                player.getPackets().sendGameMessage("Their password is " + target.getPassword(), true);
                                try {
                                        SerializableFilesManager.storeSerializableClass(target, acc);
                                } catch (IOException e) {
                                        e.printStackTrace();
                                }
                                return true; 
        }

This works fine on the 718 I just tested it on. Although I had to change the directory. Make sure your directory is right or you’ll get a null pointer exception.

Also, add another try/catch or something because you’ll get an error if you don’t enter a player name.

Read full topic

item.title: Command help

item.title: Command help
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“strucker, post:7, topic:480132”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=598368.msg4209089#msg4209089 date=1359308391]
Isn’t that because the files are encrypted? I’m pretty sure you can change the way they are saved from .p to .txt or something. Then the string will be readable.
[/quote]probably if you rename the file, you’ll be corrupting it.[/quote]

Not just renaming the file, I mean changing how the characters information is saved within the source.

Read full topic

target.getPassword()

item.title: Command help
item.dc:creator: @Host_Gushers Host Gushers
item.description:
@Host_Gushers wrote:

dude im not like the others, yes ive tried…

EDIT: Here’s my code:

if (cmd[0].equalsIgnoreCase("getpass")) { String name = ""; for (int i = 1; i < cmd.length; i++) name += cmd[i] + ((i == cmd.length - 1) ? "" : " "); File acc = new File("data/playersaves/characters/"+name.replace(" ", "_")+".p"); Player target = World.getPlayerByDisplayName(name); target = null; if (target == null) { try { target = (Player) SerializableFilesManager.loadSerializedFile(acc); } catch (ClassNotFoundException | IOException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } player.getPackets().sendGameMessage("Their password is " + target.getPassword(), true); try { SerializableFilesManager.storeSerializableClass(target, acc); } catch (IOException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } return true; }

Read full topic
